case_name: appellant-company v. Chief Inspector of Stamps

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1668 of 1966 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 1668 of 1966. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 2, 1965 of the Allahabad High Court in Civil Revision No. 1095 of 1965.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated November 2, 1965 of Allahabad High Court in Civil Revision No. 1095 of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 2, 1965 of the Allahabad High Court in Civil Revision No. 1095 of 1965. N. Dixit, for the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant-company filed suit No. 16 of 1963 against State of Uttar Pradesh and Union of India.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant-company filed suit No. 16 of 1963 against the State of Uttar Pradesh and the Union of India, inter alia, praying for a permanent injunction restraining the State of Uttar Pradesh,

facts.text: Suit prayed for permanent injunction restraining State of Uttar Pradesh from realising sugarcane cess and purchase tax amounting to Rs. 33 lakhs and odd.

anchor.surface_text: its servants and agents from realising or from proceeding to realise sugarcane cess and purchase tax amounting to Rs. 33 lakhs and odd charged under the U.P. Sugar Cane Regulation of Supply and Purchase Act, 1953,

facts.text: Taxes charged under U.P. Sugar Cane Regulation of Supply and Purchase Act, 1953; Sugar Cane Cess Act, 1956 read with U.P. Sugar Cane Cess Validation Act, 1961; U.P. Sugar Cane Purchase Tax Act, IX of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: the Sugar Cane Cess Act, 1956 read with the U.P. Sugar Cane Cess Validation Act, 1961 and the U.P. Sugar Cane Purchase Tax Act, IX of 1961. In the said suit, the appellant-company, inter-alia, alleged that the Acts for the diverse reasons set out therein were invalid and void

facts.text: Appellant-company alleged the Acts invalid and void.

anchor.surface_text: and therefore the State was number entitled to levy, companylect or recover the said cess or the purchase tax and prayed, as aforesaid. that the State should be restrained from proceeding to realise the said cess or tax.

facts.text: Appellant-company paid court-fees under sub-s. (iv)-B(b) of S. 7 on footing that relief was injunction.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant- companypany paid companyrt-fees on its said plaint under sub-s.  iv- B   b  of S. 7 on the footing that the relief sought in the suit was an injunction.

facts.text: Chief Inspector of Stamps objected to court-fees under cl. b of sub-s. (iv)-B of S. 7, contended payable under sub-s. (iv)(a) or sub-s. (iv-A) of S. 7.

anchor.surface_text: The Chief Inspector of Stamps objected to the companyrt-fees being paid under cl.  b  of sub- s.  iv-B  of S. 7 companytending that the companyrt-fees payable were as provided under sub-s.  iv   a  of s. 7 or under sub- s.  iv-A  of S. 7,

facts.text: Trial Judge rejected objections and held court-fees adequate under cl. b of sub-s. (iv)-B of S. 7.

anchor.surface_text: that is to say, on the footing that the suit was for a declaratory decree where companysequential relief prayed for was an injunction or on the footing that the suit involved cancellation of or of adjudging void an instrument securing money or other property having such value. The trial Judge rejected the objections and held that the companyrt- fees payable were adequate as cl.  b  of sub-s.  iv-B  of S. 7 applied.

facts.text: Chief Inspector of Stamps filed revision application before High Court in Civil Revision No. 1095 of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: The Chief Inspector of Stamps thereupon filed a revision application before the High Court reiterating the said objections.

facts.text: High Court rejected contention that s. 7(iv)(a) applied but held sub-s. (iv-A) of S. 7 applied as Acts were instruments securing money.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rejected the companytention that s. 7  iv   a  applied but held that sub-s.  iv-A  of S. 7 applied as the said Acts were instruments securing money within the meaning of that subsection and that though the relief claimed in the suit was injunction, in substance and effect the suit involved adjudgment of the said Acts as void.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal by special leave against High Court order.

anchor.surface_text: Hence this appeal by special leave.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that an Act passed by Legislature is not an instrument under sub-s. (iv-A) of S. 7.

anchor.surface_text: There is thus ample authority to hold that ordinarily a statute is number an instrument unless as in the case of Conveyancing Act of 1881, the definition includes it or as in the case of s. 205  I    viii  of the Law of Property Act, 1925, the statute creates a settlement and such statute is for that reason treated as an instrument.

facts.text: Supreme Court held sub-s. (iv-A) of S. 7 does not apply.

anchor.surface_text: It would number therefore be companyrect to say that the Acts alleged in the plaint to be void are instruments within the meaning of sub-s.  iv-A  of s. 7.

facts.text: High Court was not right in calling for additional court-fees under sub-s. (iv-A).

anchor.surface_text: In this view, it does number become necessary to decide whether the Acts are instruments securing money or other property having such value. Sub-s.  iv-A  of s. 7 would number, therefore, apply and the High Court was number right in calling upon the  1  1964 3 S C.R. 442.

facts.text: Supreme Court rejected contention that plaint is for declaratory decree with consequential injunction under s. 7(iv)(a).

anchor.surface_text: Assuming that Mr. Bishan Narain can urge the companytention that S. 7  iv   a  applies in the present case the companytention still fails.

facts.text: Actual relief prayed in plaint was injunction restraining State from realising cess and tax.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear from the plaint when read as a whole that though the appellant-company alleged that the Acts were void and therefore number-est for the reasons set out therein, it did number seek any declaration that they were void.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside High Court order, restored trial court order.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal, therefore, has to be allowed. The order of the High Court is set aside and the order of the trial companyrt is restored.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Shelat, J.

anchor.surface_text: N. Dixit, for the appellant. Bishan Narain and 0. P. Rana, for the respondent. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Shelat, J.

facts.text: N. Dixit appeared for appellant, Bishan Narain and O.P. Rana for respondent.

anchor.surface_text: It may be that while deciding whether to grant the injunction or not, the court might have to consider the question as to the validity or otherwise of the said Acts. But that must happen in almost every case where an injunction is prayed for.

arguments.claim: Court fees payable under cl. b of sub-s. (iv-B) of S. 7 neither 7(iv)(a) nor (iv-A) applies

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons aforesaid, we are of the view that neither cl. a of sub-s. iv of s. 7 nor sub-s. iv-A of s. 7 would apply and the court-fees payable on the plaint were under cl. b of sub-s. iv-B of S. 7.

holdings.text: Ordinarily a statute is not an instrument unless as in the case of Conveyancing Act of 1881, the definition includes it or as in the case of s. 205 (1) (viii) of the Law of Property Act, 1925, the statute creates a settlement and such statute is for that reason treated as an instrument.

anchor.surface_text: There is thus ample authority to hold that ordinarily a statute is not an instrument unless as in the case of Conveyancing Act of 1881, the definition includes it or as in the case of s. 205 I    viii  of the Law of Property Act, 1925, the statute creates a settlement and such statute is for that reason treated as an instrument.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Relies on dictionary meanings, English statutes, and precedents like Mohan Chowdhary and Emperor v. Rayangouda distinguishing statutes from formal instruments.

holdings.text: It would not therefore be correct to say that the Acts alleged in the plaint to be void are instruments within the meaning of sub-s. (iv-A) of s. 7.

anchor.surface_text: It would number therefore be companyrect to say that the Acts alleged in the plaint to be void are instruments within the meaning of sub-s.  iv-A  of s. 7.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of ordinary meaning of 'instrument' excluding legislative Acts to the taxing statutes challenged.

holdings.text: Sub-s. (iv-A) of s. 7 would not, therefore, apply and the High Court was not right in calling upon the appellant-company to pay additional court-fees under that subsection.

anchor.surface_text: In this view, it does number become necessary to decide whether the Acts are instruments securing money or other property having such value. Sub-s.  iv-A  of s. 7 would number, therefore, apply and the High Court was number right in calling upon the  1  1964 3 S C.R. 442.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Since Acts are not instruments, no need to assess if securing money; reverses High Court application of provision.

holdings.text: Assuming that Mr. Bishan Narain can urge the contention that S. 7 (iv) (a) applies in the present case the contention still fails.

anchor.surface_text: Assuming that Mr. Bishan Narain can urge the companytention that S. 7  iv   a  applies in the present case the companytention still fails.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Even assuming procedural right to argue alternative, fails on merits as no declaration sought.

holdings.text: It is clear from the plaint when read as a whole that though the appellant-company alleged that the Acts were void and therefore not entitled for the reasons set out therein, it did not seek any declaration that they were void.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear from the plaint when read as a whole that though the appellant-company alleged that the Acts were void and therefore number-est for the reasons set out therein, it did number seek any declaration that they were void.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Substance over form principle applied to plaint text: actual prayer is injunction, not declaration; alleging invalidity does not imply declaration relief.

holdings.text: For the reasons aforesaid, we are of the view that neither cl. (a) of sub-s. (iv) of s. 7 nor sub-s. (iv-A) of s. 7 would apply and the court-fees payable on the plaint were under cl. (b) of sub-s. (iv-B) of S. 7.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons aforesaid, we are of the view that neither cl. a of sub-s. iv of s. 7 nor sub-s. iv-A of s. 7 would 1  19651 1 S.C.R 712. apply and the companyrt-fees payable on the plaint were under cl.  b  of sub-s.  iv-B  of S. 7.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative conclusion: correct provision is (iv-B)(b) for injunction suits; avoids surplusage in statute.

holdings.text: The appeal, therefore, has to be allowed. The order of the High Court is set aside and the order of the trial court is restored.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal, therefore, has to be allowed. The order of the High Court is set aside and the order of the trial companyrt is restored.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Final disposition based on holdings that court fees were correctly paid under (iv-B)(b).

precedents.cited_proposition: Meaning of 'instrument' in s. 8(1) of General Clauses Act includes formal legal writings like presidential orders under Art. 359 but not statutes which are edicts of legislature
precedents.cited_holding: President's Order under Art. 359 is an instrument within s. 8(1) of General Clauses Act as it has the same connotation as statutory instrument

anchor.surface_text: Emperor v. Rayangouda Lingangouda Patil 1

precedents.cited_proposition: An instrument generally means a formal legal document or writing but does not include Acts of Parliament unless included by statutory definition
precedents.cited_holding: Order delegating power under Defence of India Rules is an instrument but Acts of Parliament are not unless statutorily defined to be
